(source #325).

portsDestroyed:
"Tsunamis,   probably   resulting   from   the   impact   of pyroclastic  flows  on  Simpson  Harbour,  occurred  at  several stages during the first day of the eruption of Vulcan. Neither  the  wave  heights  nor  the  forces  involved  are known,  but  tsunami  certainly  surged  as  much  as  100 m inland in some sections of the northern and eastern sidesof  the  harbour.  Although  several  buildings  experienced tsunami  damage,  this  was  minor  in  comparison  to  that produced by tephra fall and mudfills."
(source #326).
electricalGrid:
"The power supply was shut down at the start of the eruption (Carlson 1998). The Rabaul Power Station suffered little damage from ashfall hazards, however the station was decommissioned and the diesel generators removed (SMEC International 1999). Falling trees and buildings damaged large sections of the reticulation system. Some transformers were damaged from ashfall hazards. In 1999 approximately 40% of the original 47 transformers are in operation (SMEC International 1999). Although most of the poles in Rabaul are steel, and exposed to corrosion, SMEC International (1999) reported that most had remained intact 8 years after the eruption and could be reused."  
(source #328).
economicImpact:
Damage to public infrastructure ( roads, air transport, water supply and sanitation, electricity supply, telecomunication, education, health services, law and order) were estimated at USD 50 000 000. 
Damage to the private sector, 92% of which was business losses, amounted to USD 45 000 000. 
(source #318).

The June 15-16, 1991 : closure  of civilian airports at Manila, Puerto Princesa, and Legaspi and military airfields at Clark Air Base, Basa Air Base, Sangley Point Air Base, and Cubi Point Naval Air Station .The ash caused these airports to close for 4 days until ash could be removed from runways, taxiways, and apron surfaces.

 "The 1991 eruptions of Mount Pinatubo produced enormous clouds of volcanic ash and corrosive gases. In the days after the eruptions, these clouds had an immediate impact on air traffic routes and aircraft flying in the Southeast Asia region. In addition, the corrosive gases from Pinatubo continue to affect aircraft through 1993.  The largest ash cloud, from the June 15 eruption, was carried by upper level winds to the west and circled the globe in 22 days. […]. Sixteen damaging encounters were reported between jet aircraft and the drifting ash clouds from the June 12 and 15, 1991, eruptions. Three encounters occurred within 200 kilometers from the volcano with ash clouds less than 3 hours old. Twelve encounters occurred over Southeast Asia at distances of 720 to 1740 kilometers west from the volcano when the ash cloud was between 12 and 24 hours old. Encounters with the Pinatubo ash cloud caused in-flight loss of power to one engine on each of two different aircraft. A total of 10 engines were damaged and replaced, including all four engines on a single jumbo jet."

homesAffected: In total, 24 400 houses have been affected, of which 100 have extensive damage and 550 have moderate damage in rural areas. In urban areas, 15 houses have suffered damage. (source #308).

economicImpact:
The commercial sector suffered prejudice as a considerable proportion of the agricultural and forestry production in the affected area is taken for commercialization in the city of Leon, an important commercial center of regional and national reach. Its commercial activity was reduced several days because of the need to dedicate important efforts to the cleaning of the volcanic material in houses and streets.   A reduction of 10% of the commercial activity for an estimated space of 30 days  lead to  a decrease in sales - indirect damages - for a value of USD 1600 000.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    The industrial sector of the area was affected in seven different industrial plants whose buildings were damaged in a superficial way, especially in their roofs. Therefore, the productive activity as a whole was reduced during a period of 15 days while the repairs were being made. These losses have been estimated at around USD 1 280 000 which includes US$ 30 000 direct damages to infrastructure and USD 1 250 000 indirect damages to production.                                                                                                                                                                The telecommunications and postal sector suffered  indirect cost of USD 34 000.                                                                                                 
The total amount of damages for the transport and telecommunications sector is estimated at USD 2 010 000 with  direct damages of USD 1 882 000 and indirect damages of USD 128 000.
 The costs generated during the emergency phase have reached USD 3 580 000. 
(source #308).

The lava flow reached a length of 7,5 km from the summit. "The lower end of the flow is in the upper region of the valley of Selangbukit. It moved further following the course of this valley; far- ther down it followed the upper course of the valley of Tukad Barak and finally came to a stop 2 km south from the village of Tjut-Tjut." "Nuées ardentes d'explosion rushed down the southern and southeastern slopes continuously and devastated numerous villages and temples in the region arou
nd Selat. In this area nuées ardentes reached distances of 14 km from the summit and scorched everything on their way. Generally they followed the river courses. Numerous villages in the region of Selat like Lebih, Pura, Jehne, Sangangkuasa and Seboedi were practically completely annihilated[...]The nudes ardentes deposits fill the canyons of Jehsah, Simpar, Barak krekuk, Djanga. The nuées ardentes deposits are also found on the northern slope in the same direction of the lava flow, filling the canyons of Daja, Barak, Salangboedi, Gamongan, Linggah, Penanggungan and Lebahtjeladi. On the north slope, the greatest distance reached by nuées ardentes is about 10 ~ km from the summit which followed the course of the valley of Buluh. On the southern and southeastern slopes many villages and some parts of the forest were set on fire by the nuées ardentes[...]On May 18, [...]the areas scorched by nudes ardentes during the second paroxysmal eruption are limited to the southern, the southeastern, the northern and western sector of the volcano. The river valleys filled by nude ardente deposits are Iseh, Langon, Sabih, Buhu, Krekuk and Luah.In the valley of Iseh the nude ardente stopped near Pura, a distance of 7 km from the summit. Near Selat the nuée ardente attained a distance of 11 km; along the valley of Krekuk the nude ardente attained the same distance; here it reached a distance of 3 ½ km far- ther than the nudes ardentes on March 17. But along the valley of Luah it attained a distance of 12 km. Bombs, lapilli, sand and ash, even fell in Karangasam a distance of 17 km from the summit. areaLocation: "On March 21, fountains of lava began exiting through a 0.3-mile- (500-metre-) long vent in the ice-free Fimmvörduháls Pass, which separates the Eyjafjallajökull glacier from the larger glacier Mýrdalsjökull to the east. On April 14, lava from new fissures surfaced beneath the crater of the glacier-covered summit. The heat from the lava quickly melted and vaporized the glacier ice above. Mud, ice, and meltwater running off the volcano swelled local rivers and streams, especially the Markarfljót glacial river west of the volcano,[...]. Expanding gases from the rapid vaporization of ice started a series of moderate phreatomagmatic explosions (which result from the contact of water and magma) that sent a plume of steam and ash almost 7 miles (11 km) into the atmosphere. agricultureArea: "ash covered agricultural lands (grass and water pools) causing a shortage of water and forage for the animals."   (source #617).  The threatened resources by tephras amounted to 105 500 ha of managed grassland and 50 700 ha of natural grassland .  (source #618).
cropType: Raspberry, berry   . (source #618)

The total number of animals at the moment of the eruption, including sheep, goats and cattle, was 149 000.  the mortality  rate for animals was high due to lack of food and was estimated at 22%" i.e 32780 head of livestock.  (source #617).  "Jacobacci municipality staff estimated that livestock losses after the ash fall were around 40-60% for a total regional herd of 225000 sheep and 60000 goats."    (source #615). "the Nilahue river, which runs off the N slopes of the volcano, became clogged with ash and overflowed its banks. The press reports said that the river water was steaming, having been locally heated up to 45°C by hot volcanic material, and more than four million salmon and other fish died. " (source #619).   "In the most affected region of Argentina, the National Institute of Agricultural Technology  reported that in the province of Chubut some 750 000 sheep were affected, while in the province of Rio Negro around 60 000 head of cattle were reported to be at risk. "  (source #618).
forestArea: Trees were damaged by ash fall. "Along Route 215 transect tephra fall impacts on the forest ranged from negligible effects in areas that received a few centimeters of deposits to substantial mortality in areas where tephra thickness equaled or exceeded 25 cm."  (source #620).   6 500 ha of forest plantations and 192 500 ha of native forest were at risk.  (source #618).
airportDestroyed: The most severe disruption was the closure of Bariloche airport on 4 June. The airport was closed for 7 months, and it reopened only for buisiness on 5 july.  " Between 4-14 june numerous fligths were disrupted in Paraguay, Uruguay, Chile, southern Argentina and Brazil. The two major airports serving Buenos Aires and the international airport in Montevideo, Uruguay, were closed for several days along with airports in Patagonia.The ash plume continued to drift east, and in the second half of June and early July, widespread flight disruptions were caused in New Zealand,  Australia and South Africa." (source #615).  Summary of number of closed airports and flights cancelled for the month of June 2011  were available on  table 3 page 5435.   (source #617).
bridgesDestroyed: "Destruction of a couple of small bridges on secondary roads. As a result of the increased volume of the Nilahue River, the Juez Soto Vío bridge was seriously damaged and in February 2012, the bridge collapsed completely."  (source #618).
railroadDestroyed: The Línea Sur Railroad was closed after the eruption and reopened on 15 July 2011.  (source #621).

Jacobacci-Linea Sur, San Martin, Villa Traful, Piedra del Aguila, General Roca, Cipolleti, central and northern region of Chubut, province of La Pampa. hospitalsDestroyed: "No damage but health centres and hospitals suspended scheduled appointments and attended only emergency operations during days of high concentration of ash in suspension."   (source #617).
electricalGrid:
"The electric supply was damaged since the start of the eruption in almost all localities affected by ash fall. Supply failures had different causes, including ash accumulation on the network, damage to substations, power plant failures due to falling of both trees and poles and lightning. In Villa La Angostura, blackouts began during the first week of the eruption and lasted for one month. 
 Continuous power outages lasted until 24 June (with 40% of the town without power),followed by sporadic events after June.  In Bariloche, cuts in the electricity supply were also recorded from the beginning of the eruption, including the Alicurá-Bariloche high-voltage 132 kV power plant. Reported power cut-os were more frequent during the first and second week of the eruption,  later occurring sporadically.  In the Línea Sur, power failures were also reported. After the first week of the eruption electric cuts were sporadic. In Villa Traful, problems on the power supply were reported since the first ash fall episodes on  5 June."  (source #617).
waterSupply: Tephra fall affected the water supply at various locations. Problems with water supply were also  related to electricity breakdown.   (source #617).
economicImpact: "Tourism (National and International) is the most important source of income in Villa La Angostura, Bariloche and San Martín de los Andes.   About 80% of hotel reservations were cancelled in Bariloche during the second week of the eruption. Ski resorts of Cerro Bayo (Villa La Angostura) and Cerro Catedral (Bariloche) were covered by ash, damaging infrastructures such as lifts. 900 small enterprises and 3500 job places were threatened, and the Chamber of Commerce estimated a loss of nearly USD 48 million. Tourism decreased by  52% in the Neuquén region and by  37% in the Río Negro region with respect to the previous year, causing a total loss of USD 187 million due to hotel cancellations only (Barbier, 2012)."
